Unpopular here, but NNT has at least 2 serious problems as a primary means of communicating risk. First, NNT isn't measured, it's calculated by multiplying probabilities from various studies. Neither probability of disease nor of benefit is known with certainty; they vary from person to person in ways that are neither fully understood nor precisely measurable. Multiplication of uncertainties gives more uncertainty; the idea that an NNT of 30 is better than one of 31, or even 300, is highly questionable. NNTs should include confidence limits multiplying upper and lower limits of all the studies from which they are derived. Emphatic about the uncertainty of benefits from intervention, the referenced website fails to convey this uncertainty of derived NNTs in any useful way. Second, Zeno's the guy who said to walk a league, you had to walk half a league, and half of that, and so on. Since intervening fractions are infinite, it's impossible. As it is in fact possible to walk a league, this logic is perniciously wrong, but NNT invites it by analyzing interventions singly instead of cumulatively. How long and how many interventions are enough? The NNT for not smoking that next cigarette is probably in the billions, if calculable at all, so you might as well smoke it anyway, heart attacks and lung disease be damned. NNT is by nature a nihilist approach to all interventions, including preventive ones. But the cumulative public health impact of not doing these interventions is huge.

Oh come on ! "for all of it the essential fact is that for decades it's been Republicans that spend and Democrats that cut deficits." Are you serious or just haven't been paying attention ? Obama has been responsible for 5 of the 6 largest US deficits in our history including 4 years of over $1 trillion !!

http://www.cnsnews.com/news/article/terence-p-jeffrey/obama-has-presided...

When he came into office, there was about $7 trillion of total debt. We now stand at over $18 trillion of total debt. So he has acquired more debt in his 6 years than the sum of all the 42 Presidents that came before him.

And check out the latest CBO report showing these skyrocketing deficits caused by entitlement spending such as Obamacare:

"“Deficit reduction” there simply meant taxing first, and not starting to spend until later. But once the outlays begin, the law’s a budget-buster, not a deficit-reducer."

Liberals may not care about deficits and debt since many of their constituents receive more in benefits than they pay in taxes. But at least be honest about that. Stop trying to pretend to care about deficits when your actions strongly suggest otherwise.

Both parties have contributed to the budget deficits; note that the GOP has controlled the US House since 2011.  Note that deficits have occurred during presidencies of both parties and with varying combinations of congressional control.  Note, too, that two of the major drivers of deficits are wars and recessions, and we have had both at the same time in recent years.  Finally, regarding Democratic constituents: the poorest people in the US very rarely vote, so they aren't either party's constituents.  Moreover, if you examine groups that often vote Republican (such as the elderly in recent elections), you'll find that they receive a great deal of government benefits.

By and large, it is the state of the economy, not presidents, that determine deficits. Obama's were the result of automatic spending increases and revenue drops caused by the 2007-08 meltdown, not anything he did. The big exceptions were the quadrupling of the debt during the Reagan-Bush I years and doubling again in the Bush II years that were apparently done on purpose with tax cuts that went to the top 1% and run ups in military spending.  And please, when you are making comparisons over years, use percentage change and percent of GDP, not dollars as the basis of your remarks.
